destination.label: Manchester
destination.title: The Spirit of Rock n' Roll

content.intro:
Boasting a long history of industrial achievements, and at once cradle of football and alternative rock music, Manchester will bring out the rebel hiding in each of us.

Manchester moves at an incredible speed, with unremitting excitement typical of old labour centres that successfully shed their skin. Red brick walls make for a large part of the urban panorama, giving the north-western city a “small New York” feel. Most of the remnants of the Industrial era have been turned into lofts, office spaces and artist studios, which passersby can marvel at while strolling along the canals of Castlefield. Various other factories and warehouses will delight urban explorers looking for abandoned sites, where nature reasserts itself.
The city actually invests in that underground aspect, which you are likely to come across on every street corner. Northern Quarter is one of the defining landmarks of English alternative culture, even more so than London's punkish Camden Town. You will constantly be on the lookout for street art frescoes, whether of political and artistical overtones, or simply representing Manchester bees, the city's heraldic symbol. Enter one of its many art galleries and discover daring contemporary works of art, 500-year old Japanese etchings as well as mid-20th-century paintings by Laurence Stephen Lowry, who visually told the industrial history of the region. Manchester has always been on the forefront of global and historical heritage preservation, which you can attest to in its many libraries, full of unique manuscripts, some being several-millennia old.
It is getting dark and the streets are filled with energy. It is happy hour time in the pubs. And on game nights, the atmosphere is electric. Fans of Manchester United are dressed in red while Manchester City supporters wear blue. The two legendary teams make England proud and compete each year to win the most prestigious national and European cups. Manchester is also the embodiment of rock n' roll. It is the birthplace of bands like The Smiths, Joy Division and even Oasis, offering them a springboard before rising to worldwide fame and leaving their marks in the world of music. Capital of counterculture, the city's strong character proves fascinating. Experiment the outdoor stages and various festivals, and explore the indomitable soul of Madchester, as it is affectionately nicknamed, forever rebellious.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Manchester

seoData.seoTitle: The Spirit of Rock n' Roll
seoData.seoDescription: Boasting a long history of industrial achievements, and at once cradle of football and alternative rock music, Manchester will bring out the rebel hiding in each of us.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Manchester

content.title: Discover Manchester's abandoned heritage

introduction.small: Venture off the beaten track for an urban exploration amid abandoned and undeveloped sites.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover Manchester's abandoned heritage

paragraphs.text:
In the north of Manchester, the remains of city's industrial past did not meet the same fate as in the city centre. There, fans of urban exploration can discover factories and warehouses abandoned for decades. Although the smokestacks still point to the sky, they spit no more pollution out. Here and there, trees and plants find their way into dilapidated buildings, through the windows. The contrast between overgrown greenery and intact red bricks is striking.

Closer to the city centre, other run-down spots are well worth seeing. Do not miss the Mayfield railway station, a disused parcels depot closed in the 1980s where weeds are rampant. As for the former public Victoria Baths, they would be worthy to feature in a Wes Anderson movie. However, Manchester's must-go-to remains the Victoria Arches, huge underground spaces dating back to the 19th century. This subterranean maze was first used for storage, and then as shelters during the WWII bombings. The expansive wall mosaic and Art Deco style are invaluable testimonies of this past. Given that some of the sites are in very rough shape, it is advised to check beforehand whether they can be visited safely. In any case, nothing prevents you from gazing at them all from a distance in order to bring some original pictures back from your trip to Manchester!

content.title: Flight Club Manchester, the bar that hits the bullseye

introduction.small: In the heart of the city, Flight Club Manchester bets on the legacy of English pubs and presents you with a dart game night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Flight Club Manchester, the bar that hits the bullseye

paragraphs.text:
Darts are a classic of British bars. Here, the love for this pastime reaches new heights: 14 targets have been mounted on the wooden walls, ready to be shot at. In an always friendly atmosphere, opponents cheer on, urging each other to give their best. While waiting for the next game, other typically British and vintage bar alternatives are also available, like shuffleboards and dice, to play four twenty-one for instance. Dressed like music-hall artists with a blue shirt, suspenders and a red bowtie, waiters will gladly make you one of the house signature cocktails. Installed on one of the large bottle-green bench seats, try a Brit Spirit to get in the skin of an Englishman (Kamm & Sons British aperitif, soda, elderflower cordial and Prosecco), or toast to your victory at darts with a Sweet Success (vodka, rum, pineapple, fresh passion fruit and grenadine). At Flight Club Manchester, expect an extremely spiky night of fun!

Flight Club Manchester
Ship Canal House
98 King Street
Manchester M2 4WU

+44 (0)161 537 7250

http://flightclubdarts.com/manchester/

Menu: drinks from 4.70 GBP, from 15 GBP for one hour of darts

content.title: Climb up the Pennines by foot or bike

introduction.small: The famous mountain chain offers a large variety of nature reserves and constitutes a terrific playground for all athletes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Climb up the Pennines by foot or bike

paragraphs.text:
The Pennines mountain chain, nicknamed “England's spine”, starts in the Peak District, about 60 kilometres from Manchester, to end at the Scottish border. It is a paradise for nature lovers and outdoor enthusiasts. Real adventurers will set out to trek the “Pennine Way”, across 430 kilometres of rugged terrain for three weeks. For one-day hikes, head to the town of Edale, about an hour from Manchester, and access the Kinder Scout, one of the most famous summits in the Pennines. During the outing, which lasts about four hours, you can take a break by the Kinder Downfall, where the Kinder River forms a waterfall. A gorgeous sight! As for bike enthusiasts, a circuit runs through Rivington Pike, in the western part of the Pennines. Over thirty kilometres of cycle lanes, you will enjoy unobstructed views from the top of the needle.

Kinder Scout
High Peak S33 7ZJ
https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/kinder-edale-and-the-dark-peak/trails/kinder-scout-mass-trespass-walk

Rivington Pike
Bolton BL6 6RU
https://www.visitnorthwest.com/walk/rivington-pike/

content.title: Elnecot, industrial legacy

introduction.small: In Ancoats, Manchester's new trendy neighbourhood, the Elnecot restaurant highlights British-styled tapas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Elnecot, industrial legacy

paragraphs.text:
The establishment makes a case for its roots and the city's glorious past. In Manchester, the Elnecot restaurant displays a distinctive industrial decor, complete with pallet racks used as tables, concrete walls and retro lighting. The hype-bistro-style is totally played upon, from the visual signature to the atmosphere and the menu.

Sitting on orange bench seats, food lovers share British tapas. Take your pick among a series of small modernised traditional recipes with undertones of world cuisine: pork belly is now cooked with Korean kimchi and mushrooms find their way to your plate in Sicilian arancini. Order some braised beef cheeks in beer, Jerusalem artichokes in pesto sauce as well as spicy duck wings confit. Pair your selection with an ale, malt whisky or wine from around the world. At night, cocktails served at the bar – to be enjoyed in moderation – are once again paired with tapas. Their names hark back to the history of the place, for instance The Industrial Revolution blends gin and triple sec, or the 1212, a cocktail that references the year when the first occurrence of the name “Elnecot” has been found in the city archives.

Elnecot
41 Blossom Street
Cutting Room Square
Ancoats
Manchester M4 6AJ

+44 741 257 4324

https://elnecot.com

Menu: around 13 GBP

content.title: Hotel Gotham, back in 1920s New York

introduction.small: In an Art Deco building near Piccadilly Gardens, Hotel Gotham in Manchester harks back to the Roaring Twenties.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Gotham, back in 1920s New York

paragraphs.text:
Even though the Batman, birthed in fictitious Gotham City, is only a distant reference point, do not expect to bump into him in a corridor. Before anything else, Hotel Gotham is a tribute to 1920s New York City. Enter a time capsule through an Art Deco lobby built in 1928, now a testimony of those prosperous years.

Nicknamed “King of King Street”, the building stands out in the neighbourhood, among Manchester's posh boutiques. The hotel bets on refined eccentricity, using monochrome rugs of various geometrical patterns on the floor of the 60 bedrooms, fake furs as bedspreads, vintage suitcases scattered here and there… Do not forget to stop by the rooftop, Hotel Gotham's showpiece, as it is popular all around Manchester for the panoramic views it holds over the city.

Hotel Gotham
100 King Street
Manchester M2 4WU

+44 (0)161 413 0000

www.hotelgotham.co.uk

Rooms: from 125 GBP

content.title: A walk on the banks of Castlefield canals

introduction.small: A genuine piece of history in the heart of the city, Castlefield Basin surrounds monuments that trace Manchester's evolution, but also Northern England's as a whole.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A walk on the banks of Castlefield canals

paragraphs.text:
Wandering around Castlefield canals feels like living through Manchester's past. Today a calm and residential area, the neighbourhood is the city's historic embryo. As you explore this vast nature reserve, you will discover remnants of Roman occupation, in what was then the Britannia province: the Mamucium, an authentic 1st century AD fort, as well as an amphitheatre located on the riverbank, still used as a concert venue during the summer season.

Cross the Victorian viaduct, built in the late 19th century, and admire the “marks” of Manchester's industrial heritage: old cotton warehouses, renovated and turned into office spaces and hipster bars, coal depots, period canal locks used to pass cargo ships… Walking along the boathouses moored under centuries-old bridges, you will also come across street art frescoes that heighten the post-industrial feel that reigns in Castlefield.

Castlefield Basin
Bridgewater Canal Tow Path
Manchester M15 4SX

Mamucium
Bridgewater St
Manchester M3 4AG

content.title: Ode to art in every shape and form

introduction.small: From masterpieces of painting to the most daring contemporary creations, art is given pride of place through a multitude of galleries all around Manchester.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ode to art in every shape and form

paragraphs.text:
Paintings, textiles, sculptures, etchings… Whatever the field, Manchester stands out with the sheer number of exhibition areas. The Whitworth Art Gallery, set up on University campus in a red-brick building, is a pioneer in its kind. This century-old gallery reveals, among other things, a large collection of fabric from around the world, some of them going back as far as 300 AD. The glass and steel extension also reveals unobstructed views over the surrounding park.

Visual art lovers will stroll through the exhibition rooms of The Lowry, taking its name from British artist Laurence Stephen Lowry (1887-1976). This key figure of English painting, a large selection thereof being displayed here, was passionate in his depiction of typical scenes of industrial life in the north of the country.

In Manchester, kids are never left out. The Gallery Oldham, hybrid public space halfway between a gallery and a museum, offers playful activities for an educational introduction to painting. As for the Manchester Art Gallery, it sets up workshops where budding creators conceive their own work using salvaged materials. A delight for young and old alike.

Whitworth Art Gallery
Oxford Road
Manchester M15 6ER
+44 (0)161 275 7450
www.whitworth.manchester.ac.uk

The Lowry
Pier 8
The Quays
Salford M50 3AZ
+44 (0)843 208 6000
https://thelowry.com

Gallery Oldham
35 Greaves Street
Oldham OL1 1AL
+44 (0)161 770 4742
www.galleryoldham.org.uk

Manchester Art Gallery
Mosley Street
Manchester M2 3JL
+44 (0)161 235 8888
http://manchesterartgallery.org

content.title: National Football Museum, for fans of the sport

introduction.small: More than just a sport, football is a religion in Manchester. The city lives to the rhythm of its games and has dedicated a museum to this unique passion.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: National Football Museum, for fans of the sport

paragraphs.text:
With Manchester City and Manchester United in the fold, two famous clubs each counting some of the most impressive prize lists in the United Kingdom, Mancunians are self-defined football fanatics. In that logic, the city has built a museum devoted to the popular favourite in the hypermodern Urbis Building. Trophies, jerseys, studs and balls… all those mythical items are exhibited over three floors and tell the story of British football. The Hall of Fame is the ultimate room in telling the story of the greatest players from the two teams. Put your knowledge of sport to the test, estimate your shooting power during penalty shoot-outs and show your might as a goalie. Period football tables are scattered here and there, for the pleasure of young lads, always eager to play some. Once in the museum, out-and-out fans usually do not look at the clock. It is therefore advised to show up in the morning to fully enjoy all the interactive devices at your disposal.

National Football Museum
Cathedral Gardens
Todd Street
Manchester M4 3BG

+44 (0)161 605 8200

www.nationalfootballmuseum.com

content.title: Mackie Mayor, from old market to new temple of gastronomy

introduction.small: At the heart of an exceptional monument in Manchester's Northern Quarter, Mackie Mayor presents a large selection of products in a festive canteen atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mackie Mayor, from old market to new temple of gastronomy

paragraphs.text:
In Northern Quarter, Mackie Mayor is a trendy canteen where different styles of street food are being prepared, using local and seasonal products. Under a glass ceiling and gigantic Victorian archways, seats at the long, shared tables fill up quite fast, whether in hall or upstairs. All around the atrium, various stands give you a choice to try their own specialities.

The Grade II location (British listing of particularly important buildings of more than special interest) used to house a large covered market in the 19th century. Today, everybody gathers to enjoy original pizzas, Taiwanese baos (small stuffed and steamed brioches), traditional fish & chips, or weekend brunches… Mancunians love to come together and share moments of pure friendliness. Mackie Mayor is particularly lively after work hours, when colleagues set the world to rights, a glass in hand – yet in moderation. Wine bar or biergarten, which will it be?

Mackie Mayor
1 Eagle Street
Manchester M4 5BU

+44 (0)161 111 1111

www.mackiemayor.co.uk

Menu: around 14 GBP

content.title: Looking for street art in Manchester

introduction.small: As a city renowned around the world for its street art, Manchester puts today's trendy graffiti artists in the spotlight.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Looking for street art in Manchester

paragraphs.text:
While walking around alternative Northern Quarter, it is hard to pass by these frescoes, some of gigantic proportions, covering the street corners in the heart of Manchester. Since the Cities of Hope Festival in 2016, Manchester has become a landmark of street art, its walls covered by major figures: C215, Tankpetrol, Akse… The artists conceive huge murals, especially around Piccadilly Gardens and on Tib Street, displaying various references to pop culture, as well as in the Ancoats district, bordering Northern Quarter.

In the world of street art, landscapes change rapidly: a graffiti may disappear overnight and be replaced by a new one. Some frescoes put up some resistance, like the iconic portrait of David Bowie on Stevenson Square, or the giant chickadee spread over Port Street's red-brick wall. Venture out and look for them randomly, or during a tour set up by the Art Battle Manchester art group.

http://artbattle.co.uk

content.title: Discretion at King Street Townhouse

introduction.small: Two steps away from the Manchester Central Library, King Street Townhouse is a refined stop that hides one of the most beautiful sights in the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discretion at King Street Townhouse

paragraphs.text:
The Renaissance facade conceals an extraordinary boutique hotel: King Street Townhouse. The decor is enhanced by the use of woodwork in the lobby and the presence of a clock on ground floor, both harking back to another era. Soft and warm colours dress up the 40 Italian-style bedrooms, from beige to brown to taupe-grey. A few works by local artists add to this retro feel, notably the painting that depicts the Hacienda, Manchester's famous club in the 90s and true symbol of the city's musical history. Lay down your hat, then climb up to the seventh floor to discover the crown jewel of the hotel: beyond the spa and Jacuzzi, an oversized pool gives straight onto the roofs of Manchester and city hall's impressive bell tower. At the end of the day, you will not get enough of that major spot, admiring the different hues of a sunset that sheds a pink-orange halo of light on the urban landscape.

King Street Townhouse
10 Booth Street
Manchester M2 4AW

+44 (0)161 667 0707

www.eclectichotels.co.uk/king-street-townhouse

Rooms: from 131 GBP

content.title: Skateboard mania at Cane & Grain

introduction.small: Skaters at heart gather at Cane & Grain, industrial-style bar in Manchester, to share a pint or cocktail as a nod to pop culture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Skateboard mania at Cane & Grain

paragraphs.text:
Under the red brick facade, the sign brings tattoo parlours to mind. In the heart of Northern Quarter, the trendy Cane & Grain bar plays the nostalgic 1980s “skate” vibe. The decoration is reminiscent of industrial lofts, with period posters hung everywhere. Custom skateboards have been scattered around, serving as works of art. This sense of pop culture can be traced into the cocktail menu: Shaun of the Dead (gin, grapes, apple, lemon and passion fruit syrup) as a reference to the famous zombie spoof, the Radioactive Man (mezcal, Midori, Pimento Dram, lemon, lime and Curaçao) in tribute to the fictitious Simpsons superhero, or The Leap of Faith (rum, Curaçao, grapes, lime and cucumber), a cult skating figure. Wear your coolest sneakers, a stylish hoodie on your back and you will be more than ready to fit in!

Cane & Grain
49-51 Thomas Street
Manchester M4 1NA

+44 (0)161 839 7033

https://caneandgrain.co.uk

Menu: drinks from 4.20 GBP

content.title: Urban stroll in Manchester's alternative neighbourhood

introduction.small: Wander around the red brick walls that shelter the creator and second-hand thrift shops of Northern Quarter, a district moved by a bohemian soul.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Urban stroll in Manchester's alternative neighbourhood

paragraphs.text:
Along Piccadilly Gardens, the Northern Quarter feels somehow familiar. Maybe because it is regularly used as a filming location for movies or TV series – substituting for Victorian-era London in Guy Ritchie's Sherlock Holmes, or for Birmingham during the interwar years in the successful Peaky Blinders series. Maybe also because some of its streets look strikingly like old New York.

Here, past and present come together. The old 19th-century factories now shelter trendy industrial lofts, vintage thrift shops, independent record stores and artist studios. Fashionistas gather at the Manchester Craft & Design Centre, where creators and local artists exhibit their work, whether with textiles, jewellery or ceramics… Bargain hunters and music collectors will explore Oldham Street, looking for hidden gems in second-hand shops and other boutiques specialised in old vinyl. First in line, the famous Piccadilly Records, and its walls covered with street art.

Manchester Craft & Design Centre
17 Oak Street
Manchester M4 5JD
+44 (0)161 832 4274
https://www.craftanddesign.com

Piccadilly Records
53 Oldham Street
Manchester M1 1JR
+44 (0)161 839 8008
www.piccadillyrecords.com

content.title: Face to face with science

introduction.small: The Science and Industry Museum sheds a light on surprising, playful experiences and activities, appealing to an audience of all ages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Face to face with science

paragraphs.text:
The building in itself is worth a visit: it used to house the former Liverpool Road Station, which, from 1830 onwards, was the last stop of the first railway in the world. Today, it shelters part of the Science and Industry Museum, where everything is devised to introduce young and old to even the most challenging of scientific concepts, from basic notions of electricity and gravity to radioactivity. Each section offers playful animations in a series of educational and family-friendly experiences, as impressive as they are funny.

The museum also pays tribute to the industrial world. With regards to the location's history, the theme of transportation and its evolution is inevitably one of the high points of the circuit. On weekends, visitors can also ride an authentic steam train. As for aviation fans, they just need to cross the street and discover the second section of the premises, dedicated to aerospace. For instance, they will love the airplane flight simulator. There is definitely something for everybody.

Science and Industry Museum
Liverpool Road
Manchester M3 4FP

+44 (0)161 832 2244

www.scienceandindustrymuseum.org.uk

content.title: The libraries, treasures of Manchester

introduction.small: Manchester is home to reading and knowledge temples, unique in the world. Dawdle from alley to alley, in a setting worthy of a large-scale movie.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The libraries, treasures of Manchester

paragraphs.text:
The libraries in Manchester are renowned throughout England, above all Chetham's Library. Opened in 1653, it is the oldest of its kind in the United Kingdom and it more than made history, as, in 1845, Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels used to meet and work there. Amidst the rows of shelves, dating centuries back, it is still possible to visit the spot the two men favoured, located in one of the building's alcoves.

The John Rylands Library also offers readers an incomparable collection, consisting of rare books, some of them 5,000-years old! Within its Neo-Gothic walls, reminding of Harry Potter's universe, you will discover ornamented manuscripts from the Middle Ages. The oldest copy of the New Testament is even stored there.

Closer to us, the Central Library is the reference in Manchester, and actually the second largest across the country. Completed in 1934, it showcases impressive design, based on Rome's Pantheon with its columns and dome. Inside the building, a skylight clears the path for visitors. A monument that should not be overlooked!

Note that these libraries are freely open to the public and that, except for a few precious and rare books, it is possible to read them on site.

Chetham's Library
Long Millgate
Manchester M3 1SB
+44 (0)161 834 7961
https://library.chethams.com

Central Library
St Peters Square
Manchester M2 5PD
+44 (0)161 234 1983
www.manchester.gov.uk/centrallibrary

John Rylands Library
150 Deansgate
Manchester M3 3EH
+44 (0)161 306 0555
www.library.manchester.ac.uk/rylands/

content.title: The Principal Manchester, the city's institution

introduction.small: A ten-minute walk away from Piccadilly Gardens, The Principal Manchester will be a personal favourite during your city break.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Principal Manchester, the city's institution

paragraphs.text:
In Manchester, everybody knows this building. Its red, Victorian figure on Oxford Street topped with a bell tower never ceases to amaze passersby. Built in the 19th century for an insurance company, it now welcomes visitors of The Principal Manchester. With more than 270 rooms, the four-star hotel looks like a palace. Proof be the decoration, inspired by the location's original style, the ceiling height, the monochrome and geometrical patterns as well as the walk-in showers in the bathrooms, not mentioning the various little attentions that discreetly make the address special. As for the candy box that proudly sits on your desk, it will delight the kid in you.

The hotel's location will make it easy to walk to most of Manchester's attractions. However, if idleness were to get the upper hand, for pre-dinner drinks for instance, there is no need to even leave the hotel: the in-house bar is deemed one of the very best in town. Order a cocktail under the glass dome of the winter garden and make yourself comfortable to relax in an idyllic setting.

The Principal Manchester
Oxford Street
Manchester M60 7HA

+44 (0)161 288 1111

www.phcompany.com/principal/manchester-hotel/ ﻿

Rooms: from 121 GBP

content.title: Fress, from morning till night

introduction.small: In Northern Quarter, Fress is a hybrid and trendy place that offers brunches in the morning and cocktails at night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fress, from morning till night

paragraphs.text:
The front sign remains discreet despite the fame. In Manchester, Fress won the “Battle of the Brunch” 2017 award, making it the best in town. Eggs Benedict will be eaten up amid modernised Victorian decor, replete with bottle-green bench seats, white tiles on the walls, retro looking ceiling lights and marble table tops…

In the kitchen, meats and produce are locally farmed. Food lovers will revel in the fried chicken wings, Korean style, but also in the black pepper and halloumi cheeseburger, and the braised lamb shanks. To satisfy customers with alternate food diets, the chefs offer various vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free meals. At night, switch to original cocktails! Bunches of friends gather around the bar in an atmosphere of joyful togetherness.

Fress
62 Oldham Street
Manchester M4 1LE

+44 (0)161 236 0856

http://fressrestaurant.com

Menu: around 15 GBP

content.title: Manchester, cradle of Rock n' Roll

introduction.small: Walk in the footsteps of emblematic bands and explore the mythical stages of the Manchester music scene from the 1970s to the 1990s.Walk in the footsteps of emblematic bands and explore the mythical stages of the Manchester music scene from the 1970s to the 1990s.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Manchester, cradle of Rock n' Roll

paragraphs.text:
In Manchester, every street corner looks to be part of 20th-century Rock history. From the 1970s to the 1990s, the city was a stronghold of musical creation. Oasis, Joy Division, The Smiths, The Stone Roses… All these major international bands were born here, on the banks of the Irwell River. Follow on their heels while discovering the most mythical spots of their time.

In Southern Manchester, attend a show at the O2 Ritz, a venue that used to welcome The Smiths and the Happy Mondays on a regular basis and still keeps the rock vibe alive. Linked to the independent record label of the same name, The Factory is still very much influential in crafting a sound “made in Manchester”. In the Northern Quarter, upcoming talents take on the pubs. They are best enjoyed a beer in hand at Band on the Wall, The Fall, Joy Division and The Buzzcocks' former HQ. End your tour of north-western Rock music at a Remake Remodel night event, where you can flutter around, from one DJ set to the next, in tribute to this unforgettable time in music.

O2 Ritz
Whitworth Street West
Manchester M1 5NQ
+44 (0)1617 1441 40
www.academymusicgroup.com/o2ritzmanchester

Factory
112-118 Princess Street
Manchester M1 7EN
+44 7935 5601 76
www.factorymanchester.com

Band on the Wall
25 Swan Street
Manchester M4 5JZ
+44 (0)1618 3417 86
https://bandonthewall.org

Remake Remodel
High Street
Manchester M4 1HP
www.clubremakeremodel.co.uk

content.title: Cow Hollow, the chic of a former factory

introduction.small: In the heart of Manchester, Cow Hollow settled in a former Victorian textile factory and blends glamour with industrial style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cow Hollow, the chic of a former factory

paragraphs.text:
Proudly exposing its red bricks typical of the city, this relic of Manchester's glorious workingman history hasn't welcomed a textile worker for a long time. Instead, the building now offers travellers to stay in one of the 16 bedrooms of the Cow Hollow boutique hotel. As you set foot in, owners Mui and Amelia Rana welcome you with their usual kindness and friendliness. The couple answers the tiniest of requests, including on WhatsApp. Named after a trendy San Francisco neighbourhood, the establishment reveals a glamourous look and luxurious elements, such as marble finishes, candelabra and vintage mirrors, whilst retaining the original feel of the location. The industrial theme can be traced in the work of local artists covering the walls, the copper hues of the staircase and even the king size beds, hand-crafted with railway ties. Cow Hollow's unique charm is appreciated from the morning onwards, with a free room-service breakfast basket that includes some granola. The ideal way to start the day before venturing out.

Cow Hollow
57 Newton Street
Manchester M1 1ET

+44 (0)161 228 7277

www.cowhollow.co.uk

Rooms: from 79 GBP

content.title: The Abel Heywood, the charm of the English bed and breakfast

introduction.small: Halfway between pub and boutique hotel, The Abel Heywood offers a universe at once traditional and trendy, for engaging prices without ever cutting on quality.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Abel Heywood, the charm of the English bed and breakfast

paragraphs.text:
The Abel Heywood is before anything else an old school pub in Northern Quarter, Manchester's central district. With a wooden bar, dark wood floors and mismatched chairs, the address loves to accentuate contrasts, mixing traditions and avant-garde. On the first floor, a boutique hotel offers 15 stylish rooms that recall the bed and breakfasts of the English countryside. Fake exposed brick walls (actually a wallpaper motif) give the place a very local feeling, and the city's various sights are being displayed above the beds, using Stephen Lowry's paintings, emblematic in the region. The establishment itself was named after Abel Heywood, former mayor of Manchester in the 19th century. Even though the pub is located right beneath the rooms, the efficient soundproofing will guarantee quietness at night, but feel free to mingle with the lively crowds in the neighbourhood if you so desire! In the morning, an English breakfast awaits you. An excellent way to start off the day and soak in local culture, right before a visit to the nearby National Football Museum for instance. So British!

The Abel Heywood
38 Turner Street
Manchester M4 1DZ

+44 (0)161 819 1441

https://abelheywood.co.uk

Rooms: from 60 GBP

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Manchester
content.introduction: Manchester has a temperate oceanic climate, soft and humid. Rainfall is consistent throughout the year (with often light and long-term precipitation). Summers are moderately warm, and days of extreme heat are rare. Winters are cold but seldom frigid.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in the United Kingdom is the Pound Sterling (GBP).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Manchester International Airport
airports.description:
The Manchester International Airport is located 16 kilometres (10 miles) southwest of the city centre.
  • Three terminals:
    • Terminal 1
    • Terminal 2
    • Terminal 3 (Air France)

Getting from the airport to Manchester and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via the M56 freeway and A34 Kingsway.
    • 14,000 parking spots are available, spread throughout the three terminals:
      • Short Stay, GBP 3 for the first 30 minutes, GBP 5.40 for one hour, GBP 9 for two hours, GBP 17 for four hours and so on, with a maximum of GBP 38 for one day.
      • Long Stay, from GBP 31 for one day, GBP 50 for two days and GBP 10 per extra day after that.
    • Several car rental companies have counters on the arrivals level of each terminal.
  • By rail
    • The TransPennine Express connects the Manchester Piccadilly (city centre) in only 20 minutes and runs every 10 minutes. Standard single fare is GBP 3.69.
  • By coach
    • National Express operates express coaches that connect the airport to the Piccadilly Gardens station (in the city centre) with a travel time of 30 minutes. Standard single fare from GBP 3.20.
  • By bus
    • Bus lines 43 and 103 connect Manchester's city centre (last stop: Piccadilly Gardens) in under an hour. These two lines are operated every day, including weekends and holidays. Line 43 runs 24/7, and line 103 from 6 a.m. to 11 p.m. Standard single fare from GBP 3.50.
    • Please note: all trains, coaches and buses leave from the airport connecting station aptly named “The Station”, linking all terminals with a system of moving walkways.
  • By taxi
    • There are taxi ranks outside each terminal. Travel time to central Manchester is about 20 minutes and fares are about GBP 33.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: +44 (0)808 169 7030
  • Website: www.manchesterairport.co.uk

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Manchester
transportation.description: Manchester's public transport system is dense and convenient to explore the city.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Manchester, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organize your stay.

information.title: Manchester Visitor Information Centre
information.description:
Manchester's Tourist Information Centre offers helpful information and recommendations for your stay in Manchester and its surrounding area.
Address: 1 Piccadilly Gardens, Manchester M1 1RG
Telephone: +44 (0)871 222 8223
Website: www.visitmanchester.com

information.title: Tourist Information Centre in the United Kingdom
information.description:
The official website developed and maintained by Visit Britain, the main UK tourist board, provides a wealth of information on Manchester.
Website: https://www.visitbritain.com/gb/en/england/northern-england/manchester

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Manchester counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to the United Kingdom.

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, Quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description: There are no specific food safety risks.

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Manchester.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Manchester
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Manchester each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March 17: Saint Patrick's Day (national)
events.description: Saint Patrick's Day is a major event in Manchester, a city with an important Irish population. It gives way to the major Manchester Irish Festival, taking place for two weeks around Saint Patrick's Day with parades, shows and street plays. As part of the festival, a huge procession takes place in the streets on Saint Patrick's Day.

events.title: April 23: Saint George's Day (national)
events.description: In the United Kingdom, the National Holiday is celebrated on the feast day of Saint George, who died on this day in 303 A.D. Manchester's main festivities include a large parade, street performances and various free activities, all in a carnival-like spirit.

events.title: May: Manchester Jazz Festival (local)
events.description: Well-known and popular among Mancunians, this music festival programs concerts all around town for one week. More than 500 artists perform live to introduce their own musical universe to the audience, around one common passion: jazz.

events.title: Mid-June Sunday: Manchester Day (local)
events.description: One day during the month, Mancunians gather in the city centre to party. From morning till night, parades and street music generate a lot buzz.

events.title: July: Manchester International Festival (MIF) (local)
events.description: Organised every two years (even years), the Manchester International Festival is the city's most important cultural event. It encompasses music, dance, drama and visual arts, with international artists exhibiting their latest creations before showing them to the rest of the world.

usefulAddresses.title: Entry requirements for the United Kingdom
usefulAddresses.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be visiting the United Kingdom for less than 90 days. You must be in possession of a national identity card or a passport valid for the proposed duration of your stay.
To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Manchester and the United Kingdom, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the United Kingdom page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.openingHours: Government offices Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 5 p.m. Saturday morning from 9 a.m. to 12 p.m.

banks.openingHours: Banks Usually open Monday to Friday from 9.30 a.m. to 6 p.m. and for some Saturday from 9 a.m. to noon

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime: Start of daylight saving time: last Sunday in March End of daylight saving time: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Manchester as in the rest of the United Kingdom, there are no fixed rules for tipping. At restaurants, a service charge is sometimes included in the bill. Otherwise, it is customary to tip about 15% of the bill, unless you are not satisfied with the service. A 10 to 15% tip is also expected by taxi drivers.
